data.text: There are bears and there are BEARS. Yellowstone and the Tetons have the later. Noise helps. No smells on you helps. Bear canisters help. Pay attention to bear sighting reports. In locations where camping is heavy and tourist want to see bears or are cavalier about food, bears will be more likely to be less afraid of people. Have a bear canister, required many places, or properly hang your food. When possible cook BEFORE you reach your camp. That puts the smells elsewhere. Raccoons that are used to people are also quite assertive and determined. Control what you can. Then enjoy your time. It's all any of us can do. I hear in the UK the cows are brutal!

data.text: Most bears want nothing to do with you. They are very interested in your food though. So keep your food and anything that might smell like food away from where you are sleeping. Also don't cook near where you sleep. I once had a black bear jump up on a picnic table I was eating at. I ended up chasing it out of the campground. Black bears are easy to scare off and don't really hunt animals for food. Brown bears are a different story. If it makes you feel any better, in all of North America, there have been less than 200 people killed by bears in the last 200 years. Which makes you about 900 times more likely to be killed by a car in the US.

If you‚Äôre not familiar with Leave No Trace camping guidelines, they have good advice about how to organize a camp and gear to prevent animal invasions. LNT.org. Basically, you can clean, cook and be hygienic away from the tent and hang/bear box all the related stuff away from the tent and be fine. Practice having your bear spray handy- I had a friend have it too handy and it went off accidentally, so find a convenient but secure place for it. Overall, bears want to avoid you. If they can hear and see you, they will move away. Bears are mainly scavengers, leaving trash and choice morsels behind only conditions them to look for these easy meals, so please take kitchen discipline seriously. I‚Äôve heard a rescue/bear whistle works pretty well. I‚Äôve lived in that part of Wyoming, and honestly, unless you‚Äôre on an extended backcountry tour, the amount of traffic will keep most bears away from the main campgrounds and roads.

data.text: OK Debs if you are going into the back country, on trail or gravel track I would say, from my experience, that the risk is real but manageable. You must learn to follow simple routines/precautions. When cycling be slightly louder than normal talk loudly, ring your bell, sing etc if you have any concerns at all. In camp, tent or hut, hang all you have that had a scent in a bear bag up in the trees at night, food, deodorant, even makeup and medical supplies at least 50m from your camp. Wash and clean your teeth at least 50m from your camp. Carry to hand a whistle, an air horn and bear spray, make sure you know how to use all three. Finally urinate close to your camp so your human scent is there for the bear to smell. The risk is real, but it is small. Try to get it back into proportion, calm yourself all will be well if you follow the well documented guidance and have the recommended tools to hand. It‚Äôs a beautiful country but you must respect its nature at all times, have a great time! Go well, S.

data.text: Bears are definitely in that area, and they are grizzlies. If they hear you coming down the road, they will typically move out in the other direction. The bears that you have to fear are a momma bear with her cubs. She will be very protective of them. Don't get anywhere near them. I've personally camped out in that area, away from all other humans, and did it without any firearms or bear spray. Just be sure to keep your food in a bear-vault, away from your camp, or else suspend it between two trees high enough to be out of their reach. It's usually the bear's quest for your food that causes bad bear experiences, just like in the Yogi Bear cartoons.

data.text: We cycled the Great Divide a few years ago and like you read up a lot about bears. Before we started the trip we washed our tent to get rid of any food smells. We had a separate Ortleib bag which contained our food, toiletries and anything smelly, all of which was inside bearbags to keep smells minimal. We also carried a long, light weight rope and carabiner to hang our food bag high and away from the tent. We had bike bells on the bikes which I loved, felt like Santa's Sleigh. And we wore Bear Spray on our belts for "quick draw"! I always sing loudly when cycling which tends to scare wildlife and humans! Only saw one bear in the distance in 2 months. We had the misfortune to be there in hunting season, and the mammals with guns were scary. We loved Yellowstone which we detoured to see. Good game there is to stop and point and a thousand people will jump out of their cars and start taking pictures in the direction you are pointing. Have fun
